channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: How many species could go extinct from climate change? It depends on how hot it gets.
item.description: A new study projects biodiversity threats if global warming speeds up. Under the most extreme scenarios, about one in three species could be facing extinction by the end of the century.
item.content:encoded:
A new study projects biodiversity threats if global warming speeds up. Under the most extreme scenarios, about one in three species could be facing extinction by the end of the century.

(Image credit: Education Images/Universal Images Group via Getty)
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Lambert

item.title: Activists worry that Trump will bulldoze trans rights. Here's how they're preparing
item.description: Trump's campaign promised policies targeting the transgender community once he's in office. LGBTQ groups face fear, anxiety and uncertainty as they prep for an anticipated challenging four years.
item.content:encoded:
Trump's campaign promised policies targeting the transgender community once he's in office. LGBTQ groups face fear, anxiety and uncertainty as they prep for an anticipated challenging four years.

(Image credit: Drew Angerer)
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Diaz

item.title: Internet sleuths are trying to solve the New York CEO killing
item.description: The public is racing to find evidence that might lead to the gunman who killed health insurance CEO Brian Thompson. When does crowdsourcing detective work help police, and when can it cause harm?
item.content:encoded:
The public is racing to find evidence that might lead to the gunman who killed health insurance CEO Brian Thompson. When does crowdsourcing detective work help police, and when can it cause harm?

(Image credit: Ted Shaffrey)
item.dc:creator: Emma Bowman

item.title: Trump travels to Paris for Notre Dame Cathedral's reopening and to meet with Macron
item.description: Donald Trump is off on his first international trip as president-elect, ready to join world leaders and dignitaries in Paris for a Saturday celebration of the renovation of Notre Dame Cathedral.
item.content:encoded:
Donald Trump is off on his first international trip as president-elect, ready to join world leaders and dignitaries in Paris for a Saturday celebration of the renovation of Notre Dame Cathedral.

(Image credit: Christophe Petit Tesson)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Will Assad Survive in Syria? And Will the Conflict Widen Into a Regional War?
item.description:
Rebels in Syria are making rapid advances against the government forces of President Bashar al-Assad. Assad has managed to stay in power throughout the civil war that has engulfed his country for more than a decade. But he again finds himself in a precarious position. We weigh the chances of his political survival.

And in Lebanon, residents are watching as Syrian rebels get closer and closer to their border. There is concern that the fighting will spill over, threatening a fragile ceasefire between Israel and Hezbollah and perhaps becoming a regional war.
item.content:encoded:
Rebels in Syria are making rapid advances against the government forces of President Bashar al-Assad. Assad has managed to stay in power throughout the civil war that has engulfed his country for more than a decade. But he again finds himself in a precarious position. We weigh the chances of his political survival.

And in Lebanon, residents are watching as Syrian rebels get closer and closer to their border. There is concern that the fighting will spill over, threatening a fragile ceasefire between Israel and Hezbollah and perhaps becoming a regional war.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Northam

item.title: USDA orders testing across nation's milk supply amid rising bird flu cases
item.description: The virus has spread to over 710 dairy herds across 15 states, with California reporting the highest number of infections. At least 58 people have been infected with bird flu, including one child.
item.content:encoded:
The virus has spread to over 710 dairy herds across 15 states, with California reporting the highest number of infections. At least 58 people have been infected with bird flu, including one child.

(Image credit: Patrick T. Fallon)
item.dc:creator: Juliana Kim

item.title: The holidays are peak time for volunteers, but how about the rest of the year?
item.description: Thanksgiving Day kicks off a wave of volunteers stirred by the holiday spirit, but those in charge of local charities say they'd rather have that help at other times of the year.
item.content:encoded:
Thanksgiving Day kicks off a wave of volunteers stirred by the holiday spirit, but those in charge of local charities say they'd rather have that help at other times of the year.

(Image credit: Andrew Stelzer for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Andrew Stelzer

item.title: Election confidence among Republicans surges after Trump's win, a new poll finds
item.description: Almost 9 in 10 U.S. voters felt the November election was run well, according to new survey data. That's a jump compared with 2020 — an increase driven exclusively by Republican voters.
item.content:encoded:
Almost 9 in 10 U.S. voters felt the November election was run well, according to new survey data. That's a jump compared with 2020 — an increase driven exclusively by Republican voters.

(Image credit: Gregory Shamus)
item.dc:creator: Miles Parks

item.title: A company that turned homeowners into renters abruptly shuts down
item.description: EasyKnock, which pioneered 'sale-leaseback' deals for struggling homeowners, abruptly closes its doors
item.content:encoded:
EasyKnock, which pioneered 'sale-leaseback' deals for struggling homeowners, abruptly closes its doors

(Image credit: Sylvia Jarrus for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Thompson

item.title: Young people are dying of heat and their risks could grow, study finds
item.description: Scientists have pointed out that extreme heat is particularly dangerous for older people. A new study shows that young, healthy people are also dying too often in extreme weather.
item.content:encoded:
Scientists have pointed out that extreme heat is particularly dangerous for older people. A new study shows that young, healthy people are also dying too often in extreme weather.

(Image credit: Ulises Ruiz)
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Borunda
